column6: This paper is a multi-study paper that comprises 3 studies. In all three sub-studies similar ad-hoc measures were utilized. In Study 1, to measure "belief in dissemination intentions of Covid-19 conspiracy theories", participants read a series of conspiracy theories (8 unrelated to Covid-19, 2 related to Covid-19). For each conspiracy theory, participants rated their agreement with it (1= strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree) and also rated their intentions to share it online (1= not at all, 5 = very much). The Covid-19 related conspiracy theory scores were then used to form one latent score, whereas the non-Covid-19 related scores were used to form another, which was entered as a covariate. Similarly, in Study 2, participants read 7 Covid-19 related conspiracy theories and 3 facts about the Covid-19 pandemic. Again, participants rated conspiracy theories on 5-point scales regarding how much they agreed with them and how high their online-sharing intentions were. The 3 factual statements were treated as a "Covid-19 knowledge variable" and entered the model as a covariate. Similarly, in Study 3, participants were presented with 4 conspiracy theories about Covid-19 and asked how much they agreed with each of them.

column6: The reading task involved reading one of two (randomly assigned) fake news articles about an issue that related closely to the topic of the fake news game. The two articles were the same (insofar as this is possible) in their overarching topic, setup, structure, length, language use, and in terms of the techniques they used to mislead the audience. Both articles related to polarized and contested risk issues about immigration and the refugee crisis in the Netherlands, and assigned blame to the same organization (the European Union). Additionally, a structured and fixed number of common and popular ‘fake news’ tactics were implemented. Participants were asked to read the fake news article and fill out a second questionnaire to measure their judgments about the article
column10: We assessed participants’ familiarity with the topic on a 7-point Likert scale by asking the extent to which they were familiar with the topic in general (1 = not familiar at all, 7 = very familiar). We also asked participants how persuasive they found the article (1 = not persuasive at all, 7 = very persuasive), how much they personally agreed with the article (1 = completely disagree, 7 = completely agree, and how reliable they judged the article to be (1 = not reliable at all, 7 = very reliable). In addition, we included several open-ended items to encourage participants to actively generate answers on their own (i.e. what is the writer trying to convince you of? Which arguments did you find persuasive or not persuasive? Which arguments did you find reliable?). Finally, we assessed participants’ age and their political ideology on a 7-point scale (1 = extreme left-wing, 7 = extreme right-wing)

column6: Participants engaged in a three- stage experiment. In the familiarization stage, participants were shown six news headlines that were factually accurate (real news) and six others that were entirely untrue (fake news). Participants were randomized into two conditions: (a) The warning condition, where all of the fake-news headlines (but none of the real-news headlines) in the familiarization stage were accompanied by a Disputed by 3rd Party Fact- Checkers tag”, or (b) the control condition, where fake and real-news headlines were displayed without warnings. In the familiarization stage, participants engaged with the news head- lines in an ecologically valid way: They indicated whether they would share each headline on social media. The participants then advanced to the distractor stage, in which they completed a set of filler demographic questions including election-related questions which were used as political ideology variable for the concordance–discordance analysis. Finally, participants entered the assessment stage, where they were presented with 24 news headlines—the 12 headlines they saw in the familiarization stage and 12 new headlines (six fake news, six real news)—and rated each for familiarity and accuracy

column6: Used Okado and Stark’s (2005) misinformation false memory materials. First, subjects saw picture slides depicting an event. Two events were selected, each consisting of 50 digital color slides. Presentation order of the two events was randomized across subjects. Of the 50 slides, 12 were critical slides that would be inaccurately described in the next stage. Participants complete 30 min of filler tasks. Subjects then read narrations of the two events that had been presented in picture slides. The narratives consisted of one sentence for each slide image describing the scene depicted in the slide. For each event, 50 sentences were presented, including 12 inaccurate descriptions and 38 accurate descriptions. Participants complete 10 min filler task. Subjects then took the recognition test and then a source monitoring test. For the recognition test, 18 questions were asked for each story, 12 of which were critical questions and 6 were control questions. Each question had three possible choices as answers. Immediately after the recognition test, subjects took the source monitoring test. Subjects were asked from what presentation source they remembered the answers they indicated on the recognition test.
